Maitland-Niles: “We’re all team players, you know. We die for the team & you could see it [against #mufc] in every tackle, every chase down & every block. The manager spoke to us in the week & especially after our loss in midweek - we had to put things right.” #afc

Maitland-Niles on the win against Man United: “It’s a big, big result for us, 2-0 at home. People don’t come here & expect to win easily, but we’ve got to keep our roll going & make it hard for teams to come here so that they know they’re not going to win.” #afc

Ainsley Maitland-Niles on the win against Man United: “The fans were brilliant & we need them behind us every step of the way, just like that. Not just big games, even in the games where we don’t have to win but we should still win. It’s fantastic to hear the noise of the fans.”

Adrien Hunou: “Arsenal remain favourites, we expect a tough match, but with a fair amount of space.”

Speaking to Ouest-France, Rennes forward Adrien Hunou looked ahead to Thursday’s 2nd leg clash with Arsenal after beating Caen 3-1 on Sunday.

“Arsenal remain favourites for the second leg. We expect a really difficult match on the pitch, with a fair amount of space. There is only a two-goal difference. But anyway, we are going to have to value our strengths like we did in the first leg.”

On Arsenal vs. Manchester United:

Yes, we watched a bit of it in the dressing room, it was on the TV. We saw that they were winning 2-0, they will want to demonstrate a big reaction, it will be an important match for them, like it is for us, which they have prepared well for by beating Manchester United. As I was saying, what is most important is that we remain focused on our performance.

The Gunners are said to have a long-standing interest in the Spaniard, but he is not considered a top target by the club.

Alex Lacazette is now eligible for Thursday’s Europa League clash with Rennes after his Uefa ban was reduced to two matches.

Our striker was initially serving a three-match ban following a red card in our last-32 first-leg game against BATE Borisov, but will now be able to play in this week’s match having already served his reduced two-match ban.

The Uefa Control, Ethics and Disciplinary Body’s decision reads as follows:

“The appeal lodged by Arsenal FC has been partially upheld. To suspend the Arsenal FC player Alexandre Lacazette for two (2) Uefa competition matches for which he would be otherwise eligible for serious rough play.

"Note: Lacazette has already served the two-match suspension following Arsenal FC’s Uefa Europa League matches - round of 32 second-leg match against BATE Borisov on February 21, and round of 16 first-leg match against Rennes on March 7."
